title: Iliad
author: Homer
description: The foundational epic of Greek literature, depicting the wrath of Achilles during the final year of the Trojan War. Primary source for Greek gods' involvement in mortal affairs.

title: Odyssey
author: Homer
description: The epic tale of Odysseus's ten-year journey home from Troy, featuring encounters with gods, monsters, and mortals. Essential source for Greek mythology and religious practices.

title: Theogony
author: Hesiod
description: A systematic account of the origin and genealogy of the Greek gods, from primordial Chaos to the reign of Zeus. The definitive source for divine genealogy.

title: Works and Days
author: Hesiod
description: A didactic poem containing the myth of Prometheus, Pandora, and the Five Ages of Man. Provides insight into Greek religious and moral philosophy.

title: Homeric Hymns
author: Various (attributed to Homer)
description: A collection of thirty-three anonymous hymns celebrating individual Greek deities. Major source for myths of Demeter, Apollo, Hermes, and Aphrodite.

title: Poetic Edda
author: Anonymous
description: A collection of Old Norse poems from the medieval Icelandic manuscript Codex Regius. Primary source for Norse mythology including the Voluspa prophecy and Havamal.

title: Prose Edda
author: Snorri Sturluson
description: A manual of poetics that preserves Norse mythology through three sections: Gylfaginning (mythology), Skaldskaparmal (poetic diction), and Hattatal (verse forms).

title: Mahabharata
author: Vyasa (traditional attribution)
description: The longest epic poem in existence, containing the Bhagavad Gita. Chronicles the Kurukshetra War and includes extensive Hindu mythology and philosophy.

title: Ramayana
author: Valmiki
description: The epic tale of Prince Rama, his exile, the abduction of his wife Sita by demon king Ravana, and his alliance with the monkey god Hanuman.

title: Rigveda
author: Various Vedic sages
description: The oldest of the four Vedas, containing 1,028 hymns to the Vedic deities including Indra, Agni, and Varuna. Foundation of Hindu religious tradition.

translators.name: Stephanie W. Jamison & Joel P. Brereton

title: Kojiki (Records of Ancient Matters)
author: O no Yasumaro
description: The oldest surviving chronicle of Japan, containing myths of creation, the divine couple Izanagi and Izanami, and the sun goddess Amaterasu.

title: Nihon Shoki (Chronicles of Japan)
author: Prince Toneri and O no Yasumaro
description: The second-oldest book of classical Japanese history, providing alternative versions of myths found in the Kojiki and additional material.

title: Book of the Dead
author: Various Egyptian priests
description: A collection of funerary spells intended to assist the deceased in the afterlife. Major source for Egyptian underworld mythology and the weighing of the heart ceremony.

title: Pyramid Texts
author: Anonymous Egyptian priests
description: The oldest known religious texts in the world, carved on pyramid walls. Primary source for early Egyptian mythology and solar worship.

title: Popol Vuh
author: Anonymous K'iche' Maya
year: c. 1554-1558 CE (written; oral tradition much older)
description: The creation narrative of the K'iche' Maya, telling of the Hero Twins and multiple attempts by the gods to create humanity. The most important text of Mesoamerican mythology.

title: Enuma Elish
author: Anonymous Babylonian priests
description: The Babylonian creation epic describing the rise of Marduk to supremacy among the gods and his creation of the world from the body of Tiamat.

title: Epic of Gilgamesh
author: Sin-leqi-unninni (standard version)
description: The oldest known epic literature, following the hero-king Gilgamesh and his companion Enkidu. Contains the earliest flood narrative and themes of mortality.

title: Aeneid
author: Virgil
description: The Roman national epic following Trojan hero Aeneas from the fall of Troy to the founding of Rome. Primary source for Roman mythology and religious practice.

title: Metamorphoses
author: Ovid
description: A narrative poem of transformations spanning from the creation of the world to the deification of Julius Caesar. Contains over 250 Greek and Roman myths.

title: Bibliotheca (Library)
author: Pseudo-Apollodorus
description: A comprehensive handbook of Greek mythology organized by genealogy. Invaluable reference for many myths not preserved elsewhere.

title: Mythology: Timeless Tales of Gods and Heroes
author: Edith Hamilton
description: A widely influential introduction to Greek, Roman, and Norse mythology. Known for its accessible prose and emphasis on the human elements of ancient myths.

title: The Hero with a Thousand Faces
author: Joseph Campbell
description: The foundational work of comparative mythology introducing the concept of the 'monomyth' or hero's journey. Analyzes mythological narratives from cultures worldwide.

title: The Masks of God
author: Joseph Campbell
description: A four-volume comparative study of world mythology covering Primitive, Oriental, Occidental, and Creative aspects of human mythological expression.

title: The Golden Bough
author: James George Frazer
description: A pioneering work of comparative religion and mythology examining death-and-rebirth deities, sacred kingship, and ritual practices across cultures.

title: The Greek Myths
author: Robert Graves
description: A comprehensive retelling and analysis of Greek mythology with extensive commentary on sources and interpretations. Known for its matriarchal theory.

title: The Norse Myths
author: Kevin Crossley-Holland
description: An acclaimed retelling of the Norse myths from the Eddas, noted for its poetic prose and fidelity to the original spirit of the tales.

title: Gods and Pharaohs from Egyptian Mythology
author: Geraldine Harris
description: An accessible introduction to Egyptian mythology with beautiful illustrations, covering creation myths, the Osiris cycle, and pharaonic religion.

title: Hindu Myths: A Sourcebook
author: Wendy Doniger (O'Flaherty)
description: Translations of key texts from the Vedas, Brahmanas, Puranas, and epics, organized thematically around creation, destruction, and the lives of major deities.

title: Japanese Mythology
author: Juliet Piggott
description: An introduction to Shinto mythology from the Kojiki and Nihon Shoki, covering the divine creation, the sun goddess Amaterasu, and legendary heroes.

title: Maya Cosmos: Three Thousand Years on the Shaman's Path
author: David Freidel, Linda Schele, & Joy Parker
description: A scholarly exploration of Maya mythology combining archaeological evidence, art history, and deciphered hieroglyphic texts.

title: Ancient Iraq
author: Georges Roux
description: A comprehensive history of Mesopotamia from prehistory to the Hellenistic period, including detailed coverage of Sumerian, Babylonian, and Assyrian mythology.

title: The Oxford Dictionary of World Mythology
author: Arthur Cotterell
description: A comprehensive reference work covering mythological figures, themes, and narratives from cultures across the globe.

title: The Complete World of Greek Mythology
author: Richard Buxton
description: A beautifully illustrated scholarly overview of Greek mythology, examining myths in their cultural, religious, and artistic contexts.
